run.lit: Before we cover this weeks code example, let's step back for a moment to talk more about function composition. Although it was covered in Brian’s [video1](http://
), there’s been good feedback that I glossed over it in Tutorial 1 and should've spent a little more time on it. So here goes:
You should be asking “why is mapping over Box better than using ordinary functions (a -> b)?”
Well its not always better. Ordinary functions are simpler to read, write, use, and you can reason about their behavior more easily.
For example it is simpler to do the following in PureScript
func x = foo $ bar $ baz $ quux $ x
or func x = foo <<< bar <<< baz <<< quux $ x
or func x = (quux >>> baz >>> bar >>> foo) x
which ever is easier for you to understand.

tut01/src/Main.purs)) using composition on ordinary functions. I chose forward composition (>>>) because I personally prefer showing long transformation chains in sequence from the beginning, and often I’ll put them on separate lines.

Where Functors shine is when you’re mixing categories and you need to bridge from one category to the other. First, what is a category? Well we’ve seen two categories already from Tutorial 1 - Box was one category, and Maybe was another. They each contained our transformed values at some point during the transformation chain. If you recall, we passed the value from Maybe back into Box by using the `fromMaybe` function. Still this example was a contrived, because we were able to compose using ordinary functions just fine.
Think about using functors to replace the word categories

But in the wild you’ll often be mixing categories when you’re using third-party frameworks or libraries that have their own way of representing values with categories that differ from yours. Then you’ll likely provide an adaptor layer that transforms that third-party category to your category or vice-versa. Functors help you with this transition from one category into another. But we need a few more tools in our tool box, so we’re not quite ready to show this just yet. I’ll come back to this topic a little later in the tutorial series.
For example, we can compose a few ordinary functions then use the Box constructor to bring it into a Box, assuming some library function requires inputs to be in Box.

Our Tutorial 2 code example is solving the simple problem of applying a discount, given a string of money and a string of percentage. We’re going to use our Box construct from Tutorial 1 to solve it. Note that it would've been perfectly fine to use ordinary function composition to solve this problem. But we’re learning the Box functor so let’s stay focused on Box and its instances, with map in the spotlight.
Converting our money string to a number
First MoneyToFloat in JavaScript, followed by PureScript
The PureScript example below is much more interesting.

In the replace function, notice the constructor `Pattern`, which is used by the `purescript-strings` module to match our substring. Note I chose to use a substring rather than a regular expression just to keep it simple. Its a viable solution, because given proper input there should only be one dollar sign in the currency string. Our new substring “” is wrapped in a `Replacement` constructor which specifies a replacement for our pattern.

Let’s move on to `unsafeParseFloat` on the last line - it’s our first encounter with PureScript’s FFI capabilities which are partially covered in **Calling JavaScript from PureScript** in the next section below.

In JavaScript’s `parseFloat` function, strings that cannot be converted to a number return NaN. But we told the type system that we’re always returning a `Number` - Ouch! It would be a crime to return NaN without warning the user of this potential hazard, and that’s not how we roll in PureScript. We need to deal with it - no excuses. Normally, in production, returning a Maybe or Either Constructor would be a good choice, and we’ll cover these in detail in future tutorials. This way the type signature makes it clear that the user of this function will have to deal with possibility of NaN. But, in order to avoid conflating the example with these abstractions, I chose to create `unsafeParseFloat` (see [Main.js](

In PureScript and other functional languages, its a common idiom to designate functions as either `safe` or `unsafe` whenever there’s a possibility of side effects, such as Exceptions. For example, you might create a foreign declaration `unsafeHead` which returns the head of an array. And in order to deal with the possibility of an empty array, you can decide to throw an error exception. Therefore designating it with the `unsafe` prefix warns the user that they should ensure that `unsafeHead` is never called with an empty array argument.
Converting our discount string to a number

PercentToFloat Next up is `percentToFloat` which is really nothing new, with one exception. We can start immediately with a `Box` of `str.replace( )`, we don't have put the string in the box first before applying a transformation function. It comes down to your preference for readability and performance.
Now the equivalent in PureScript. Again, nothing new here, other than what was described above.

Both the JavaScript and PureScript code samples, are nice examples of using nested closures to compute `cost` and `savings` for use wihin the final expression. But the big ‘ah ha moment’ is that we use `fold` instead of `map`. Had we used `map` on each instead of `fold`, the result would’ve been two boxes deep `Box ( Box ( x ) )`. Plus there’s no type checker in JavaScript, and so you’ve might’ve gone mapping your merry way into perhaps hours of debugging. I’m not even sure whether TypeScript or Flow would catch this problem. You can try, but I doubt it.

Now here where’s the PureScript compiler can save you hours of frustration in this case. If you try using `map` instead of `extract`, the compiler will raise an error message, seeing as you’re calling `percentToFloat` with a `Box String` instead of `String` . That’s the beauty of an intelligent type checker, thank you very much! I encourage you to go ahead an try this yourself, so that you become familiar with PureScripts compiler error messages. Again, from Tutorial 1, be aware that `extract` is different than `fold` from the JavaScript example above. Because `extract` does not apply a function before taking the value out of the box. That’s why I’ve got `extract` as a function of the string transformations, and its tucked inside parenthesis instead of chaining.

One final note: besides using ordinary function composition (see Function Composition with ordinary functions), there’s a more canonical approach to writing the `applyDiscount` function. So for those who like to see what’s in store for future tutorials, I’ve included this canonical pattern as a bonus example in the [code](

This tutorial would not be complete without spending a little more time on PureScript’s _foreign function interface_ (or FFI). It simple terms, the FFI enables communication to and from JavaScript. This topic is covered very well in Phil Freeman’s [PureScript made Easy](

) (free to read online), so I highly recommend you read his chapter on it. But if its TL;DR time again, then I’ve covered calling JavaScript from PureScript below. That’s what we did by calling our `safeParseFloat` function.
To call an existing JavaScript function from PureScript we create a foreign import declaration in Main.purs:
We also need to write a foreign Javascript module, in our case Main.js:

Pulp will find .js files in the src directory, and provide them to the compiler as foreign Javascript modules. By convention, I called it Main.js as a signal to the user that the foreign declaration for unsafeParseFloat is defined in Main.purs.
I hope you appreciate the simplicity of PureScripts FFI. I believe its a real advantage over other implementations such as ports in Elm.
